Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research:RCN:UrBioNet: A global network of urban biodiversity research and practice
Award.AbstractNarration:
Over half of the world's human population lives in cities, making the human experience of nature increasingly defined within urban areas. In order to understand how cities can support both humans and biodiversity, greater collaboration is needed among scientists, urban planners, and design professionals. This project will create a research coordination network to bring together these disciplines to study the factors affecting biodiversity in cities (UrBioNet). The network will facilitate engagement of scientists globally and develop databases and materials focusing on the plants and animals of cities that are relevant to local residents, urban planners, and managers. This project will expand existing global databases of plants and birds in cities and develop new databases of bats, fish, and insect pollinators of cities and their surrounding regions. The network will focus on the compilation and monitoring of urban biota in areas of high regional biodiversity, such as tropical cities and cities within biodiversity hotspots. Three scientific working groups will use information collected in this network to answer questions regarding the ecological relationships of different species to urbanization, with consideration of cultural and social aspects, and develop recommendations for monitoring urban ecosystems. Key activities in support of the network include: network-wide meetings; workshops; and the development of an online graduate course on urban biodiversity. UrBioNet will further serve the scientific community by supporting the development of global, regional, and local databases to test hypotheses on the patterns of species based on the physical, climatic, and social features of cities.

Outcomes from this project will enhance our understanding of the ecology of cities and provide useful information to planners and managers for the monitoring and preservation of biodiversity in urban regions. By targeting activities in regions with less data availability, UrBioNet will enhance knowledge transfer among regions with different degrees of investment in urban ecological research and monitoring. The network will develop monitoring protocols that will standardize data collection methods and be economically feasible to implement. Planners, managers, and practitioners will be active participants in the network. Online courses will be developed for graduate students at 13 universities (including two historically black universities) in the U.S., and UrBioNet will involve undergraduate students through campus-based biodiversity monitoring projects led by network participants at up to 21 universities in the U.S., Europe, Africa, Asia, and South America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Urban Biodiversity Reserach Coordination Network (UrBioNet) is an international network of researchers and practitioners working on urban biodiversity.  We proposed four goals for UrBioNet:  to develop a database on biodiversity in the world’s cities with a particular focus on cities in the global south; to engage scientist and practitioners working on urban biodiversity; to understand the importance of socioeconomic and demographic factors in driving urban biodiversity; and to understand the role of life history traits and patterns in shaping urban biodiversity.  UrBioNet expanded the global coverage of urban biodiversity datasets to include 381 cities. Database includes cities in countries within Southeast Asia (Bangladesh, Cambodia, East Timor, India, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Philippines, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Vietnam), Latin and South America (Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Cayman Islands, Mexico, Panama, Puerto Rico), Africa (Ethiopia, Guinea Bissau, Kenya, Niger, Rwanda, Sao Tome and Principe, Seychelles) as well as new cities in US, Brazil, Colombia, Canada, Australia, Europe (Bulgaria, Czech Republic, Denmark, Finland, Germany, Hungary, Poland, Portugal, Solvenia, Switzerland, Russia, UK), Asia (Japan, India, Nepal).

UrBioNet developed a network of over 400 members from 41 countries who are interested in urban biodiversity. Eight countries (USA, Australia, UK, Germany, Canada, Brazil, India, China) were represented by 10 or more members. One hundered ninety members were interested in sharing biodiversity data.  

UrBioNet convened three workshops involving researchers and practitioners working on urban biodiversity. The first working group addressed socioeconomic variables that could shape biodiversity in the world’s cities leading to a paper published in Landscape and Urban Planning that used qualitative comparative analysis to understanding the role of socioeconomic and demographic variables as predictors of biodiversity in different kinds of cities. The second workshop used new databsets from 60 collaborators who shared data on reptiles, bats, birds, bees, reptiles, and amphibians. These datasets were used in a synthesis project to identify important life history traits associated with the distribution of species within the world's cities. The third workshop brought together a group of pople working on urban biodviversity management, monitoring, planning, an design.  This group explored the ways that practitionerss use biodiversity data and the innovative approaches to management, monitoring, planning and design that are emerging in the world's cities. 

UrBioNet network members have given presentations to scientific societies (Ecological Society of America, Ecological Society of Australia, Urban Biodiversity & Design Network, North American Congress for Conservation Biology, Society for Conservation Biology, The Wildlife Society), as well as presentations to several universities. Practitioners and the general public have been reached through presentations at the New Jersey Chatper of the  American Society of Landscape Architects, US Forest Service, San Francisco Estuary Institute, Society for Ecological Restoration – New England, and articles in the The Nature of Cities website. This work has been covered in popular and scientific press including the National Wildlife Federation Magazine.

Education and outreach were important components of UrBionet.  Network members developed an online urban biodiversity course based around a series of modules that can be used as stand-alone units or as a single course.  UrBioNet members have modified the Crosstown Walk teaching module that can be used in different settings to teach key concepts about about socioeconomic and demographic factors that drive biodiversity and other urban ecosystem processes (https://sites.rutgers.edu/urbionet/resources/crosstown-walk-project/).

UrBioNet developed an online database containing species list for cities and spatially explicit data showing locations of species within cities (https://mospace.umsystem.edu/xmlui/handle/10355/46235), a Facebook page (http://facebook.com/urbionet) that will continue to be places for sharing information on urban biodiversity.
